text: There is a story I know. It’s about the earth and how it floats in space on the back of a turtle. I’ve heard this story many times, and each time someone tells the story, it changes. Sometimes the change is simply in the voice of the storyteller. Sometimes the change is in the details. Sometimes in the order of events. Other times it’s the dialogue or the response of the audience.

But in all the tellings of all the tellers, the world never leaves the turtle’s back. And the turtle never swims away. One time, it was in Tehran I think, a dark-haired boy in the audience asked about the turtle and the earth. If the earth was on the back of a turtle, what was below the turtle? Another turtle, the storyteller told him. And below that turtle? Another turtle. And below that? Another turtle.The boy began to stare, enjoying the game, I imagine. So how many turtles are there? He wanted to know.
The storyteller shrugged. No one knows for sure.
The truth about stories is that that’s all we are.
The iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami tells us: “A story starts before we encounter it and concludes long after we have turned away.”

I used to think that in order to fully live, one must belong somewhere first. I lived in a society of paradoxical freaks who believed that as long as you live, you serve someone or something. I didn’t truly live because I believed in a different idea than the one I was taught. In 2012 my family decided to emigrate from Iran.
A hard decision followed by the tragic exit of my grandmother from our lives.
We were ready to leave and to never look back.
My teachers also looked forward to my departure because I didn’t truly belong there, they believed. “It’s good that you’re leaving, you know.” One of them told me.
options: Leave while you can, it will always hurt to come back

text: I’ll never forget the day I saw his face among many other political prisoners on national television. A lesson to be learned for the younger generations, they probably thought.
He was physically beaten up and emotionally torn out.
He didn’t belong because he believed in an idea, the wrong one that is.
Many moons later, upon his release, he moved to a university in Boston, or Rome, or London, or far away enough that would eventually forbid him from his mother’s last living days.
options: Flowing around the globe, in search of a home

text: It was around the second year of my residence in a truly wonderful and free country that I finally learned about their true history.
I saw the fruits of their labour.
From the corner of a street in downtown Montreal, a seemingly old torn out man came to me with a funny accent and said “For all the walks you take on this land, you owes me a drink.”
My integration-aide teacher in high school told me some of the history behind the man’s demand, and I eventually learned that it’s not only in Iran where some people aren’t supposed to belong.
options: It's better to not question it much.

text: My teacher ended her story like this “It’s good that you’re living here, you know.”
Yussef lived his days missing his motherland.
He cried and screamed,
and longed for his past days
fighting for his ideals.
